channel.title: NYTimes Filtered
channel.description: Filtered news feed based on specified categories.

item.title: ‘White Lotus’ Highlights the Way Old Friends Bring Out Our Worst Selves
item.description: “The White Lotus” highlights a common phenomenon in long-term friend groups: Nobody ever changes.
item.author: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Title not available
item.description: Description not available

item.title: Othello and Iago, a Marriage Made in Both Heaven and Hell
item.description: Because Shakespeare gave his hero and antihero equal weight, the contest between the actors playing them has never been that easy to call.
item.author: Ben Brantley
item.content:encoded: Paul Robeson, the first Black man to play Othello on Broadway, with Uta Hagen as Desdemona in the 1943 production. His watershed portrayal was wildly acclaimed.

item.title: Martha Argerich, the Elusive, Enigmatic ‘Goddess’ of the Piano
item.description: At 83, the Argentine-Swiss pianist is at the peak of her powers. But she doesn’t want to talk about it.
item.author: Javier C. Hernández
item.content:encoded: “I want to hide.” Argerich in Basel, Switzerland.

item.title: At the New Frick, Magicians Come Out of the Woodwork
item.description: Textile weavers, tassel-makers, lighting restorers, cabinet makers and muralists forged new traditions at the sumptuous Beaux-Arts museum.
item.author: Patricia Leigh Brown
item.content:encoded: The Grand Staircase leading to the newly opened family rooms has a restored chandelier and decorative screen covering the pipe organ.

item.title: Eating ‘Family Style’ May Have Set the Stage for Life as We Know It
item.description: Under microscopes, scientists found that giant single-cell organisms were able to vacuum up more food when they are stuck together.
item.author: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: A New Dinosaur Museum Rises From a Hole in the Ground in New Jersey
item.description: The museum hopes that after learning about the planet’s prehistoric past, people will do more to preserve Earth’s future.
item.author: Kenneth Chang
item.content:encoded: Ric Edelman, left, whose donation helped build the Edelman Fossil Park & Museum, looks up at a re-creation of a baby hadrosaur in one of the exhibits.

item.title: A Quarter-Billion Dollars for Defamation: Inside Greenpeace’s Huge Loss
item.description: A pipeline company’s lawsuit against the environmental group could chill free speech, experts said. First Amendment issues are likely to figure prominently in an appeal.
item.author: Karen Zraick
item.content:encoded: Greenpeace representatives outside the courthouse in Mandan, N.D., where the jury ruled against the environmental organization this month.

item.title: A Concept Album About Dennis Hopper? The Waterboys Made One.
item.description: The latest addition to Mike Scott’s eclectic catalog features Fiona Apple, Bruce Springsteen, Steve Earle and more exploring the life of the actor and director.
item.author: David Peisner
item.content:encoded: Dennis Hopper in his many guises has inspired the musician Mike Scott over the years.

item.title: Fisher Center at Bard Announces Civis Hope Commissions
item.description: The Fisher Center at Bard has announced a wave of works by artists including Suzan-Lori Parks, Courtney Bryan, Barrie Kosky and Lisa Kron.
item.author: Joshua Barone
item.content:encoded: From left, the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks, the composer Courtney Bryan, the director Barrie Kosky and the playwright Lisa Kron, all artists who will work on Civis Hope Commissions at the Fisher Center at Bard.

item.title: My Friend’s Show Was Kind of Terrible. What Do I Say When I See Them?
item.description: You can always consider telling the truth, but it may not be advisable in this case.
item.author: Michael Paulson

item.title: In 50th Anniversary Shows, Danspace Project Pulls Past Into Present
item.description: As part of its 50th anniversary, the East Village institution presents reimagined dances by Ishmael Houston-Jones and Fred Holland, Donna Uchizono and Bebe Miller.
item.author: Gia Kourlas and Brian Seibert

item.title: Review: A Kronos Quartet Glow Up: New Players, Newly Lustrous Sound
item.description: The venerable quartet returned to Zankel Hall with a typically eclectic program and a newfound emotional intensity.
item.author: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim

item.title: A Pack of April Fools
item.description: A survey of the many fools who have been immortalized in song, featuring Aretha Franklin, Bow Wow Wow, the Stone Roses and more.
item.author: David Renard
item.content:encoded: Aretha Franklin, who was not known to suffer fools.

item.title: 20 New Books to Read in April: Joan Didion, Emily Henry, Tina Knowles and more
item.description: A posthumous Joan Didion book, Emily Henry’s latest romance novel, Tina Knowles’s memoir and more.

item.title: ‘Dying for Sex,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV this Week
item.description: The Hulu show starring Michelle Williams premieres, and the third season of “White Lotus” wraps up.
item.author: Shivani Gonzalez
item.content:encoded: Michelle Williams in “Dying for Sex.”

item.title: ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3, Episode 7: Lovers and Fighters
item.description: “The White Lotus” tells us only enough about the characters’ pasts to explain some of the choices they make. Sometimes this works; sometimes it doesn’t.
item.author: Noel Murray
item.content:encoded: Carrie Coon in “The White Lotus.”

item.title: The Conductor Joana Mallwitz Mixes Intensity With Approachability
item.description: Joana Mallwitz, one of Germany’s fastest rising stars, makes her Metropolitan Opera debut in “The Marriage of Figaro” on Monday.
item.author: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.content:encoded: “You develop a relationship with such a work,” Mallwitz said of “The Marriage of Figaro.” “You get to know each other.”

item.title: How to Live in the Mall
item.description: Want your living space a stone’s throw from the Aéropostale and Hot Topic? A new documentary, “Secret Mall Apartment,” will show you the way.
item.author: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: 10 Wild Clips to Help You Understand Andy Kaufman’s Greatness
item.description: The standup, who’s the subject of a new documentary, expanded the ambition of comedy. These videos show how far ahead of his time he was.
item.author: Jason Zinoman
item.content:encoded: Andy Kaufman’s Elvis impression was one of the few bits he took seriously.

item.title: 12 Plays and Musicals Across the U.S. to Brighten the Spring
item.description: On stages across the country, there is no shortage of adventurous work, including plays by Lauren Yee, Larissa FastHorse and Zora Howard.
item.author: Laura Collins-Hughes

item.title: Through Tears, ‘Mid-Century Modern’ Makes Them Laugh
item.description: Partway through filming Season 1, the beloved cast member Linda Lavin died. To honor her, the remaining cast and crew decided the show must go on.
item.author: Alexis Soloski

item.title: Traveling to Finland for Lessons on Happiness
item.description: Can forest walks, cold plunges and talking to trees make you happier? An anxious American went to Helsinki to see if what she learned there could lift her spirits back home.
item.author: Britta Lokting

item.title: Title not available
item.description: Description not available

item.title: Title not available
item.description: Description not available

item.title: Brightline Brought High-Speed Rail to Florida. Can the Public Sector Follow?
item.description: In Florida, Brightline has proved that it can operate reliable, well-designed passenger trains that people want to ride. Can the public sector do the same?
item.author: Michael Kimmelman

item.title: 5 Train Routes That Highlight the Beauty of Europe
item.description: Most of these routes run daily, come at no extravagant cost and have special details that will make your journey comfortable, scenic and memorable.
item.author: Palko Karasz

item.title: Steak Fries: Deservedly Reviled or Underappreciated Edible Spoons?
item.description: They may be America’s least popular fry, but some chefs are still devoted to them.
item.author: David Segal
item.content:encoded: Steak fries, once widespread, have fallen out of favor with diners in recent years.

item.title: How to Pack a Cheaper, Healthier and Better Lunch
item.description: Be a better “bring your lunch to work” person with these expert tips.
item.author: Ali Slagle
item.content:encoded: Make a lunch you’ll dream about.

item.title: Five Ingredients, Five Stars, No Joke
item.description: Garlicky Alfredo beans are “outrageously good.”
item.author: Emily Weinstein

item.title: Roasted Salmon Recipe for Spring
item.description: The peas are fat and sweet, the radishes are small and peppery. It’s time for this Kay Chun stunner.
item.author: Tejal Rao
item.content:encoded: Kay Chun’s roasted salmon with peas and radishes.

item.title: This Tree Wants to Be Struck by Lightning
item.description: Before a discovery in a Panamanian rainforest, “it seemed impossible that lightning could be a good thing for the trees,” a scientist said.
item.author: Rebecca Dzombak
item.content:encoded: Dipteryx oleifera has emerged as something of an arboreal lightning rod in the rainforests of Panama.

item.title: Art World Celebrates the Frick Collection’s Long-Awaited Opening Gala
item.description: A joyous reunion for art lovers at the Frick Collection’s gala offered a private viewing of iconic works from the 14th through the 19th centuries.
item.author: Rachel Sherman
item.content:encoded: The Frick Collection is set to open to the public later this month.

item.title: ‘A Tiny Bit of Math’ Might Improve Your Heart Health, Study Suggests
item.description: Your average daily heart rate is a useful metric; so is your daily step count. Combining the two might be even better.
item.author: Matt Richtel

item.title: Three Restaurants Where Big Groups Are No Problem
item.description: We’re talking indoor pavilions, prix fixe deals and informal hangs.
item.author: Nikita Richardson
item.content:encoded: For $75 per person, you and 17 of your closest friends can enjoy a group dinner at Phoenix Palace in Chinatown.

item.title: Val Kilmer: Three Memorable Movies to Stream
item.description: Kilmer’s film career ranged from slapstick comedy to some of the most memorable films of the 1980s and ’90s.
item.author: Hank Sanders and Tim Balk

item.title: RFK Jr. Turns to a Discredited Vaccine Researcher for Autism Study
item.description: David Geier has been hired as a senior data analyst at H.H.S. According to several people, he will examine any potential links between vaccines and autism that were debunked long ago.
item.author: Christina Jewett, Emily Baumgaertner Nunn and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.content:encoded: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, at the U.S. Capitol in March. Mr. Kennedy has long held that there is a link between certain vaccines and autism.

item.title: Senate Confirms Bhattacharya and Makary to H.H.S. Posts
item.description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya will direct the N.I.H., and Dr. Martin A. Makary will lead the F.D.A. Both have reputations as medical contrarians.
item.author: Benjamin Mueller

item.title: March 2025 Partial Solar Eclipse: Where and How to Watch
item.description: If you’re on the East Coast, wake up early to try and catch the moon take a bite out of the sun on Saturday.
item.author: Katrina Miller

item.title: E.P.A. Offers a Way to Avoid Clean-Air Rules: Send an Email
item.description: Referring to a little-known provision, it said power plants and others could write to seek exemptions to mercury and other restrictions and that “the president will make a decision.”
item.author: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.content:encoded: A coal-burning power plant in Colorado in 2023. The Biden administration had put new rules in place on emissions from power plants.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Spots Auroras on Neptune for the First Time
item.description: The James Webb Space Telescope identified the lights in the distant planet’s atmosphere, which could not be seen by earlier telescopes or spacecraft.
item.author: Robin George Andrews
item.content:encoded: The Near-Infrared Spectrograph on the James Webb Space Telescope picked up cyan splotches of auroral activity, right, that could not be picked up by the Hubble, left, and other telescopes in the past.

item.title: Masaki Kashiwara, Japanese Mathematician, Wins 2025 Abel Prize
item.description: Masaki Kashiwara received the honor, often regarded as the Nobel Prize in mathematics, for work that combined different mathematical fields to solve challenging problems.
item.author: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Molly Young on Space and Music
item.description: A Booker-winning novel; a rocking essay collection.

item.title: Last Tango in the Guggenheim
item.description: Members of the dance company Ballet Hispánico weren’t the only ones who swirled amid the art in the museum’s rotunda during a recent presentation and tango class.
item.author: Annie Aguiar and Vidhya Nagarajan

item.title: 5 Podcasts Where Truth Is Stranger Than Fiction
item.description: These twist-filled shows can offer a real-world escape from the drumbeat of news.
item.author: Emma Dibdin

item.title: Lucy Dacus on the Art of Frames (and Busting Out of Them)
item.description: The singer and songwriter chats about the movies (“Paris, Texas”), music (SZA) and books (“Healing Back Pain”) that shape her world as she releases her fourth LP.
item.author: Julia Jacobs
item.content:encoded: “Framing is such a huge part of art,” Lucy Dacus said. “What are you putting in the confines of the frame? What are you filling in time? What are you putting in front of people?”

item.title: Maryland’s Kermit the Frog Commencement Choice Gets Mixed Reaction From Students
item.description: The University of Maryland says it is honoring Jim Henson, an alumnus, with its choice of commencement speaker. Some students think it is avoiding “real issues.”
item.author: Callie Holtermann
item.content:encoded: Kermit the Frog will deliver a commencement speech at the University of Maryland on May 21.

item.title: New Songs From Mumford & Sons, Maren Morris, Lucy Dacus and More
item.description: Hear tracks by Mumford & Sons, Mon Laferte, the Swell Season and others.
item.author: Jon Pareles
item.content:encoded: Maren Morris works on finding the will to heal herself on “Carry Me Through,” from a new album, “Dreamsicle,” due in May.

item.title: 11 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.author: The New York Times
item.content:encoded: Paul Rudd, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Death of a Unicorn,” by the writer-director Alex Scharfman.

item.title: Best Historical Fantasy Books
item.description: The author of “The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi” recommends fantastical tales grounded in real history.
item.author: Shannon Chakraborty

item.title: ‘Secret Mall Apartment’ and the Case for Art in Unexpected Places
item.description: Jeremy Workman’s documentary looks back at a project that may sound like a joke but had serious underpinnings.
item.author: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: 3 Video Games You May Have Missed in March
item.description: Karma: The Dark World takes inspirations like BioShock and “Severance” to the next level with creepily surreal and bizarrely utopian set pieces. Expelled! and Centum also delight.
item.author: The New York Times

item.title: Have Young People Really Turned MAGA?
item.description: Feeling empowered is different from numerical growth.
item.author: Neil Gross

item.title: Hiking the Cactus to Clouds Route in Palm Springs, Calif.
item.description: The Cactus to Clouds ascent just outside Palm Springs, Calif., is grueling, but natural treasures, and a speedy trip down, await anyone who is up to the challenge.
item.author: Dina Mishev and Max Whittaker
item.content:encoded: Cactus to Clouds, on Mount San Jacinto near Palm Springs, Calif., has been rated the fifth-hardest day hike in America.

item.title: Why Is It So Hard to Find a Good Nonalcoholic Wine?
item.description: Extracting the alcohol from a wine can also remove richness and body from the finished product. But these 10 producers have cracked the code.
item.author: Eric Asimov

item.title: Celebrating Eid al-Fitr With a Couple Dozen Doughnuts
item.description: For some Muslim Americans, the best (and only) way to celebrate Eid al-Fitr is with a couple dozen doughnuts.
item.author: Sarah Khan
item.content:encoded: At Detour Doughnuts in Frisco, Texas, crescent moon shaped doughnuts are an Eid specialty.

item.title: A Queens Bar Becomes a Beacon for Inspired Mexican American Food
item.description: Like the big cat that presides over this Ridgewood restaurant, Hellbender knows how to stretch — mixing late-night vibes with polished cooking.
item.author: Melissa Clark
item.content:encoded: The inventive Mexican American menu, thrumming music and convivial vibe at Hellbender make it an ideal place to bring a large, taco-loving group.

item.title: George Foreman Turned a Home Grill Into a Culinary Heavyweight
item.description: The former boxer transformed American cooking, and himself, with an appliance that remains a cultural touchstone.
item.author: Kim Severson
item.content:encoded: While boxing fans will always remember his enduring legacy, George Foreman holds a special place in the hearts of 1990s cooks who wanted lower-fat meals.

item.title: Easy Pasta Recipes to Welcome Spring
item.description: These vibrant, produce-packed meals are just the thing for celebrating warmer days.
item.author: Krysten Chambrot
item.content:encoded: Andy Baraghani’s pasta salad gets its green from spinach and basil.

item.title: Chicken Cobbler Is an Easier Potpie
item.description: Mark Bittman’s classic recipe turns a little chicken (just two boneless thighs) and a lot of vegetables into a cozy Sunday dinner.
item.author: Sam Sifton
item.content:encoded: Mark Bittman’s chicken cobbler.

item.title: ‘I’d Always Wanted to Make Biryani, and This Did Not Disappoint’
item.description: Naz Deravian’s reader-favorite chicken biryani is a beautiful weekend dish, its preparation a satisfying process with delicious results.
item.author: Sam Sifton
item.content:encoded: Naz Deravian’s chicken biryani.

item.title: Recipes That Use Green Onions
item.description: They’re versatile and welcome in all sorts of dishes, like quick stir-fried noodles, toasted sesame waffles and a platter of roasted spring vegetables.
item.author: Tanya Sichynsky
item.content:encoded: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s ramen with charred scallions, green beans and chile oil.

item.title: Want to Eat More Fish? Start Here.
item.description: These 14 delicious recipes — including this one-pan roasted fish with cherry tomatoes — make eating more fish a delight and a breeze.
item.author: Mia Leimkuhler
item.content:encoded: Lidey Heuck’s one-pan roasted fish with cherry tomatoes.

item.title: A Puttanesca for Early Spring
item.description: Melissa Clark’s pasta with green puttanesca is a lovely showcase for spring’s tender greens and green garlic (though plain old garlic is great, too).
item.author: Kim Severson
item.content:encoded: Melissa Clark’s pasta with green puttanesca.
